newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: CRICKET-ADAMS AND BROWNE SPARE WEST INDIES' BLUSHES.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-ADAMS AND BROWNE SPARE WEST INDIES' BLUSHES.

text.p: Middle-order
batsman Jimmy Adams and wicketkeeper Courtney Browne spared West
Indies' blushes as they beat an invitational side by 48 runs in
a limited overs tour match on Tuesday.
The sixth-wicket pair rescued West Indies from a perilous
66 for five after 19 overs by adding 98 to help lift the final
score to a comparatively respectable 218 for eight in their 50
overs.
In reply, the Northern Territory Invitation XI, a side
containing seven Sheffield Shield players, struggled to 170 all
out in 42.5 overs in a carnival atmosphere for this rare visit
by a touring side to Australia's arid interior.
Adams contributed a valuable 67 while Browne scored exactly
50 after West Indies captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and
elected to bat.
Earlier, West Indies delighted the crowd of more than 4,000
by inviting local chidren to join them on the ground for their
pre-match practice drills.
Several hundred children from isolated Aboriginal
settlements in the Territory attended the match after travelling
hundreds of kilometres by bus to Alice Springs.
The Invitation XI side contained four players based in the
Northern Territory, a vast, sparsely populated area stretching
from the central desert to Australia's northern coast.
Western Australia captain and wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist,
who led the Invitation XI, compiled an impressive, unbeaten 64
to further his claim for a test call-up.
Gilchrist, who scored an unbeaten century for his state
side when they were beaten by West Indies in a three-day match
last weekend, is pushing for a place in Australia's team for the
first test, starting in Brisbane on November 22.
Widely regarded as a likely successor to Ian Healy, for
whom he deputised when Australia's wicketkeeper was injured on
the recent tour of India, Gilchrist is also being touted by
local media as a potential specialist batsman for the current
test side.
Fast bowler Kenneth Benjamin was the pick of the West
Indies bowlers here, taking three for 25 in eight overs.
